rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 18   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 25   Value: 8
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 11   Value: 14
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 12   Value: 28
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 23   Value: 38
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
I’ll play with an eye on raising my total point value.  
My current totals:  
- Wheat: 18 × 5  = 90  
- Wood: 25 × 8  = 200  
- Sheep: 11 × 14 = 154  
- Brick: 12 × 28 = 336  
- Ore: 23 × 38  = 874  

Total value = 1 654.

Everything I trade must leave me (after the swap) with a higher final value.

General preferences:
- Prepared to give Wheat, Wood, or moderate numbers of Sheep.
- Prepared to receive Brick and Ore (high unit value).
- Brick is my scarcest high-value item (12 vs 23 Ore), so I’m keen to acquire more.
- Accept tiny losses in favorable trades if it sets up later gains.

Opponent has not spoken yet; I open with an offer that asks for Brick and offers lower-value resources in exchange.

[Offer: 6 Wheat, 4 Wood -> 3 Brick, 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
I now have the new information that my first offer (6 Wheat, 4 Wood → 3 Brick, 1 Ore) was rejected.  
Based on the original values, that offer had a value loss for me, so its rejection isn’t surprising; I need to structure trades that are attractive to Player 1 yet maintain or increase my total value.

I’ll try a simpler, more favorable-looking trade: giving away 3 lower-value Wheat for 1 high-value Brick. It has a net value gain for me (15 → 28) and Brick can be scarce on the table, so Player 1 may view it as balanced.

[Offer: 3 Wheat -> 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
Let me scan the logs first to confirm the game state:

- Turn 1:  
  – P0 offered 6 Wheat, 4 Wood → 3 Brick, 1 Ore.  
  – P1 rejected.  

- Turn 2:  
  – P0 made no new offer, rejected P1’s non-existent offer (an automatic action).  

- Turn 3:  
  – P0 offered 3 Wheat → 1 Brick.  
  – P1 rejected.  

Net effect: no trades have occurred; my resource counts and values are still:

Wheat 18 (value 5)  
Wood 25 (value 8)  
Sheep 11 (value 14)  
Brick 12 (value 28) – most scarce and highest demand  
Ore 23 (value 38)

My total value now  
= (18×5)+(25×8)+(11×14)+(12×28)+(23×38) = 2 050

Brick is the tightest resource for me, and every extra Brick adds 28 value. Ore is similarly valuable but I have plenty. I also have excess Wood and plenty Sheep that I can spare.

Next turn is Turn 4. I will propose a slightly more generous trade that still improves my total value while giving Player 1 a better perceived rate than my last two attempts.

Analysis of the rejected bids  
– My first bundle offer (6 Wheat 4 Wood → 3 Brick 1 Ore) had an asking price of 3 brick (≈84 value) for only 6 wheat (≈30) + 4 wood (≈32) = 62, perhaps too pricey for P1.  
– My single-Wheat-for-single-Brick swap (15 value for 28) was similarly imbalanced.

This time I will give P1 more intrinsic value per brick so it is mutually beneficial: offer 5 Wheat + 3 Wood → 2 Brick.  
That’s 5×5 + 3×8 = 49 value for 2×28 = 56 value.  
The value gap (7) still favors P1 slightly. Importantly, from my viewpoint 49 of my lower-marginal-value resources (W and Wo) become 56 of my scarce high-value resource (Brick), still a net gain of +7 value to me.

[Offer: 5 Wheat, 3 Wood -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
I evaluate the balance of their proposed 2 Sheep → 1 Ore trade.

- The value I place on 2 Sheep is: 2 × 14 = 28  
- The value I place on 1 Ore is: 1 × 38 = 38  

Giving away Ore worth 38 to gain back only 28 is a losing deal (-10 to my total value). I therefore reject it.

[Deny]

Let me first check how much the current proposals hurt/help me:

Player 1 just offered  
[Offer: 2 Brick → 1 Ore]

- I give up 1 Ore → I lose 38 value points.  
- I receive 2 Brick → I gain 2×28 = 56 value points.  

Net change: +18 value points.  
That increases my total value, so the trade is worthwhile.

[Accept]

rounds.response:
Thought process (concise, private):

- I currently have:
    18 Wheat(5), 25 Wood(8), 11 Sheep(14), 12 Brick(28), 23 Ore(38)  
- Last Accepted trade: I gave 1 Ore (value 38) and received 2 Brick (value 56). Net gain = +20.

Trading principle: keep giving my least-valued resource and acquiring his, but still at a favorable value ratio.

My least valuable resource is Wheat (5 per unit).  
They offered 2 Brick(56) for 1 Ore(38) → ratio ≈ 1.47 in my favor.  
If they’re willing to give 2 Brick per Ore, they’re fairly desperate for Ore.

Next, try to get more high-value resources by dumping Wheat.

I’ll offer → 7 Wheat (35 value) for their 2 Brick (56 value). 1.6:1 ratio is quite friendly; perhaps they accept.

Action:

[Offer: 7 Wheat -> 2 Brick]
